subject: Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: ... I too would have though that this trick would work: Use Roe for CMU R and CMU ER (where before Utter+Roe was CMU ER ) But I see too that this fails
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "paulhtremblay" <phthenry@...>
wrote:
>
> I just CMU, and it lists "around," "arrest,"
> and "arrive," as starting with an ER sound, the same sound in NURSE. I
> checked on dictionary.com, and these words do not in fact start with
> ER, so the CMU is wrong, which means I must do a lot of manual editing
> here.
>

I too would have though that this trick would work:

Use Roe for CMU "R" and CMU "ER" (where before Utter+Roe was CMU "ER")

But I see too that this fails and it really does look like the fault
of the CMU. It looks like the CMU is so fiercely rhotic that they did
not pay attention to these "minor" differences (that or the grad
student that did the work had a hangover that day)

But since this is really only a test, maybe before doing a ton of
manual labor we can devise some automation by asking our knowledgeable
friends:



Does anyone know a rule that strongly (but not necessarily always)
determines when R makes the /r\/ sound and when it makes the /3/
sound? Maybe something about neighboring consonants or vowels?




--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "paulhtremblay" <phthenry@...>
wrote:
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "paulhtremblay" <phthenry@>
> wrote:
>
> > On the same vein, I can also regenerate the dictionary to change what
> > would result in QS "ar" into just "r," and then we can actually have a
> > test case in the news and see how your proposal works. Of course, I'll
> > have to make sure the "ar" is within the same syllable, but I think
> > the CMU dictionary uses numbers after the mark off syllables. I
> > ignored these numbers before, but they may be useful now.
> >
>
> Okay, that won't work. I just CMU, and it lists "around," "arrest,"
> and "arrive," as starting with an ER sound, the same sound in NURSE. I
> checked on dictionary.com, and these words do not in fact start with
> ER, so the CMU is wrong, which means I must do a lot of manual editing
> here.
>
> Paul
>
